channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: South Korea's president faces calls to resign or be impeached
item.description: Opposition parties have filed a motion to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol and plans for rallies in major cities are underway.
item.content:encoded:
Opposition parties have filed a motion to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol and plans for rallies in major cities are underway.

(Image credit: Chung Sung-Jun)
item.dc:creator: Se Eun Gong

item.title: D.R. Congo's mining capital is at the heart of Biden's bid to counter China in Africa
item.description: Kolwezi has some of the world's largest copper and cobalt reserves and that makes it a key location at the heart of the U.S. and China's jostle for mineral supremacy on the African continent.
item.content:encoded:
Kolwezi has some of the world's largest copper and cobalt reserves and that makes it a key location at the heart of the U.S. and China's jostle for mineral supremacy on the African continent.

(Image credit: Junior Kannah)
item.dc:creator: Emmet Livingstone

item.title: 'Guardian' journalists strike to protest sale of sister paper 'Observer'
item.description: Nearly 500 journalists have walked out of the Guardian and its sister paper, the Observer, to protest what they see as a betrayal of the paper's values: the planned sale of the Observer to a startup.
item.content:encoded:
Nearly 500 journalists have walked out of the Guardian and its sister paper, the Observer, to protest what they see as a betrayal of the paper's values: the planned sale of the Observer to a startup.

(Image credit: Oli Scarff/Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: David Folkenflik

item.title: Inside RFK Jr.'s nonprofit's legal battles over vaccines and public health
item.description: The nonprofit Children's Health Defense that Kennedy led has filed nearly 30 federal and state lawsuits since 2020, many challenging vaccines and public health mandates.
item.content:encoded:
The nonprofit Children's Health Defense that Kennedy led has filed nearly 30 federal and state lawsuits since 2020, many challenging vaccines and public health mandates.

(Image credit: Chip Somodevilla)
item.dc:creator: Shannon Bond

item.title: Supreme Court hears challenge to law banning gender-affirming care for trans kids
item.description: At issue is a Tennessee law that bans access to hormones, puberty blockers, and other treatments for trans kids in the state.
item.content:encoded:
At issue is a Tennessee law that bans access to hormones, puberty blockers, and other treatments for trans kids in the state.

(Image credit: Kent Nishimura)
item.dc:creator: Nina Totenberg

item.title: Search goes into the night for Pennsylvania woman who may have fallen into a sinkhole
item.description: A grandmother looking for her lost cat apparently fell into a sinkhole that had recently opened above an abandoned coal mine and rescuers worked late into Tuesday night to try and find her.
item.content:encoded:
A grandmother looking for her lost cat apparently fell into a sinkhole that had recently opened above an abandoned coal mine and rescuers worked late into Tuesday night to try and find her.

(Image credit: Gene J. Puskar)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: To many residents in southern Lebanon, life doesn't feel like there's a ceasefire
item.description: Israel's military has imposed a curfew and created a no-go zone where villagers are prohibited from going home to villages across southern Lebanon. NPR speaks to residents inside.
item.content:encoded: Israel's military has imposed a curfew and created a no-go zone where villagers are prohibited from going home to villages across southern Lebanon. NPR speaks to residents inside.
item.dc:creator: Jawad Rizkallah

item.title: North Carolina's voter ID law just got its first big test
item.description: For more than a decade, North Carolina has seen a bitter back-and-forth over voter identification rules. The requirement finally got its first major test in last month's presidential election.
item.content:encoded:
For more than a decade, North Carolina has seen a bitter back-and-forth over voter identification rules. The requirement finally got its first major test in last month's presidential election.

(Image credit: Grant Baldwin)
item.dc:creator: Steve Harrison

item.title: Trump team signs an agreement with the DOJ for security clearances
item.description: The new agreement will help Trump officials on agency landing teams access classified information needed to prepare to take over on Jan. 20.
item.content:encoded:
The new agreement will help Trump officials on agency landing teams access classified information needed to prepare to take over on Jan. 20.

(Image credit: Kent Nishimura)
item.dc:creator: Tamara Keith

item.title: Will Trump's next term make him richer?
item.description:
Just before Donald Trump took office the first time, he held a press conference, announcing that he would turn over control of his business empire to his sons.

He said he wanted to address concerns about conflicts of interest even though he maintained he didn't really have to. Saying, "I could actually run my business. I could actually run my business and run government at the same time. I don't like the way that looks, but I would be able to do that if I wanted to."

Trump's second term may put that theory to the test. The former and future president hasn't yet announced any plan to wall himself off from his businesses while in office, and Trump's businesses like his many hotels and resorts could benefit substantially from his actions as President.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.
item.content:encoded:
Just before Donald Trump took office the first time, he held a press conference, announcing that he would turn over control of his business empire to his sons.

He said he wanted to address concerns about conflicts of interest even though he maintained he didn't really have to. Saying, "I could actually run my business. I could actually run my business and run government at the same time. I don't like the way that looks, but I would be able to do that if I wanted to."

Trump's second term may put that theory to the test. The former and future president hasn't yet announced any plan to wall himself off from his businesses while in office, and Trump's businesses like his many hotels and resorts could benefit substantially from his actions as President.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

(Image credit: Joe Raedle)
